lines.content: You know, everyone’s lucky but me;
Unless you somehow missed the giant title that said the same thing.
That’s all I had to say in this stanza.
Yesterday I saw on the news what would make me weep,
A starving child from Africa given food for free.
Nobody ever offered any to me.
What have they done to deserve their mead?
And that afternoon I could not stop my shock and stare;
Some lucky bastard in his own wheel chair.
And all he had to do was lose his God damn legs.
Man, life’s just never fair—that’s all I can say.
And I heard years ago some lucky few got helicopter rides for free;
All the way from New Orleans.
And that place was its own swimming pole, too.
And of course they get free money afterwards—what’s new?
All I have is this boring-ass house, made out of ugly-ass gold,
Where there’s mountains of food I have to hold.
And do I get to be taken to work in a car? No!
All I get is some private jet, which just blows.
As you can see life’s just out to get me.
I mean, I’m so God damn pathetic that I’m writing poetry.
